lines.text: Oh no, don't!... Give up, that is. It's very interesting. Nobody makes love like that in Indiana.
I don't want to miss Boo's wedding. I've missed so many of my own.
How are you fixed for money?
As usual, I'm un-loaded.
By the way, our date *is* off, isn't it? When I didn't hear from you for three years, I leaped to that conclusion. You heel.
You're being charming, reasonable and very boyish. Unless you've changed, that means you're about to drink someone's blood. Probably mine.
Even when I was making love to you, I had the feeling that you were wondering what time it was.
And, you have to forget I'm a woman.
Linda Gilman is not a woman, Linda Gilman is not a woman... Have a cigar.
Thanks... I'll smoke it after breakfast.
One by one, you promised every girl at Crestville High to help her with her homework.

[with hangover]
Ohhhh...
It seems you're an expert on multiplication.
Man's best friend is the apple!
I need somebody like you. Now you're good looking, charming, a good sense of humor, intelligent and an attractive personality.
Are you offering me a job or proposing to me?
How do you want your drink?
In a glass.
Corey, this will be a nineteen page feature about five thousand words. Here are my background notes. We'll call it "June Bride".
Isn't that a little daring?
I beg your pardon?
No harm done.
No harm done? The whole June issue of "Home Life" just went flying out that door.
You don't mean to tell me that you think you an do something with this funeral parlor?
Wait, you'd be surprised. Why the sour darling smirk?
Oh, you're incredible, utterly incredible! Perched on that pinnacle of masculine ego, peering down at poor defenseless females! and pitying them! Because they don't have beards!
Don't be ridiculous, if you had a beard I wouldn't look at you twice!

[looking around the office]
Pretty 'luxe.
Ought to be, it's real leather.
Must be like living in a wallet.
Paula, darling? Would you be a dear, sweet girl and hand me my notes from that drawer? I have the distinct feeling that if I lean over any further my left eye will fall out.
Why haven't you ever married? Certainly there were men who interested you.
Only one.
Why didn't you marry him?
Mostly because I wasn't asked.
Why didn't you ask him?
You were listening again.
It's the only way I ever hear anything.
Really Mrs. B!. If we're going to get anywhere in three days, you've simply got to stop rippling.
[Begins pounding on her again]
Tell me, ummm, how are your uncles?
Fine. All except Uncle Henry. We don't talk about him.
Well what's the matter with Uncle Henry? A little soft in the head maybe?
Oh, no. He's a Democrat.
